snippet.textDisplay: No doubt it changes toe but not from toe out to less toe or zero toe as said. That would not be visible by eye. What it does is to change from normal slight toe out to massive toe in only to heat up front tyres when ever those front tyres are not hot enought. Normaly this is needed in long straits and cold or wet conditions.
snippet.textOriginal: No doubt it changes toe but not from toe out to less toe or zero toe as said. That would not be visible by eye. What it does is to change from normal slight toe out to massive toe in only to heat up front tyres when ever those front tyres are not hot enought. Normaly this is needed in long straits and cold or wet conditions.

snippet.textDisplay: I don't think that this system is legal. Toe angle of tyres are a part of the suspension geometry and parc ferme regulations explicitly state that the suspension gepmetry can't be changed or worked on after the car leaves the garage for qualifying and the race.
snippet.textOriginal: I don't think that this system is legal. Toe angle of tyres are a part of the suspension geometry and parc ferme regulations explicitly state that the suspension gepmetry can't be changed or worked on after the car leaves the garage for qualifying and the race.

snippet.textDisplay:
Of the top of my head, it is cheating. You can't change the suspension settings while in motion.


10.2.2 Any powered device which is capable of altering the configuration or affecting the
performance of any part of any suspension system is forbidden.
10.2.3 No adjustment may be made to any suspension system while the car is in motion.



"Any" suspension system. So how does changing the toe not affect other suspension components?
The castor will mean that the toe will affect 'other' suspension systems.


We shall see
snippet.textOriginal:
Of the top of my head, it is cheating. You can't change the suspension settings while in motion.


10.2.2 Any powered device which is capable of altering the configuration or affecting the
performance of any part of any suspension system is forbidden.
10.2.3 No adjustment may be made to any suspension system while the car is in motion.



"Any" suspension system. So how does changing the toe not affect other suspension components?
The castor will mean that the toe will affect 'other' suspension systems.


We shall see

snippet.textDisplay: I really do not understand the 'difficult' to use assumptions.  Considering the natural flow of the G forces under acceleration and breaking, the process/movements involved to manage the DAS system seem rather natural and intuitive tbh, and likely to applied by drivers pretty subconsciously with very little actual effort of adjustment to style/driving method required at all.  To me, that's the most genius part of whole design, how the control system just seems to flow with what the car and driver are experiencing on track at the time anyway.
snippet.textOriginal: I really do not understand the 'difficult' to use assumptions.  Considering the natural flow of the G forces under acceleration and breaking, the process/movements involved to manage the DAS system seem rather natural and intuitive tbh, and likely to applied by drivers pretty subconsciously with very little actual effort of adjustment to style/driving method required at all.  To me, that's the most genius part of whole design, how the control system just seems to flow with what the car and driver are experiencing on track at the time anyway.

The men in black win!!
Mercedes the super brain!
Last season everyone performed, including the so-called experts, and this year a new prank.

snippet.textDisplay:
Leave it to ze Germans to come up with a brilliant, seemingly obvious innovation that cascades into a bunch of benefits.

In one simple change they’ve made it so they have optimal toe in for cornering and straight line performance, less tire wear (which will also improve braking) and arguably better aero angles going into and coming out of corners and most likely better fuel economy from lack of tire friction. It’s minute, but all this will add up over the course of each race, and probably much more depending on each track (once they dial it in).

I imagine they’ll cater the toe angles more or less aggressive depending on how twisty each track is, so it’s almost a permanent advantage (and I’d bet the farm that other top teams are gonna be pulling all nighters to try an duplicate it).

This’ll be yet another year of Merc dominance, and while it does get tiring to see the same team win handily every year, it’s stuff like this that makes you realize they deserve it. One thing you can’t say about Mercedes is that they rest on their laurels.
snippet.textOriginal:
Leave it to ze Germans to come up with a brilliant, seemingly obvious innovation that cascades into a bunch of benefits.

In one simple change they’ve made it so they have optimal toe in for cornering and straight line performance, less tire wear (which will also improve braking) and arguably better aero angles going into and coming out of corners and most likely better fuel economy from lack of tire friction. It’s minute, but all this will add up over the course of each race, and probably much more depending on each track (once they dial it in).

I imagine they’ll cater the toe angles more or less aggressive depending on how twisty each track is, so it’s almost a permanent advantage (and I’d bet the farm that other top teams are gonna be pulling all nighters to try an duplicate it).

This’ll be yet another year of Merc dominance, and while it does get tiring to see the same team win handily every year, it’s stuff like this that makes you realize they deserve it. One thing you can’t say about Mercedes is that they rest on their laurels.

snippet.textDisplay:
I wonder if it is significant that it changes toe-in/out and not camber?

Toe is inarguably in the plane of steering, so you are clearly steering, whereas if it changed camber you would be introducing a suspension change, altering set-up.
snippet.textOriginal:
I wonder if it is significant that it changes toe-in/out and not camber?

Toe is inarguably in the plane of steering, so you are clearly steering, whereas if it changed camber you would be introducing a suspension change, altering set-up.

snippet.textDisplay: so depending on the race track and the time and effort merc is willing to put into it, will matter how effective this is.  I doubt it will be useful at a few of the street races (singapore, monico) as there is not much  to gain on a straight vrs the corners,  on the important tracks for it merc now needs to do 2 times their homework.  Assuming 2 positions/track for the system ( forward and back)  then how much do you compromise for a given  position for a given track.  And how much adjustment can you get in total?    Wile a fun tool i doubt every team has the capability to manage it correctly even if they implement it.

snippet.textDisplay:
So... they have shown off this idea early. All the other teams rush off and copy it. Then they finally reveal in Adelaide that they also have a 2nd part of the design they haven't revealed yet.
Maybe pushing the steering wheel UP raises the rack via a pivot point and reduces camber for maximum contact patch for braking?
Other teams... Oh crap.. back to the drawing board!

snippet.textDisplay:
Im going to be pissed if this gets banned. This is not anything to do with the suspension, this is not an aerodynamic device, this is likely not powered. F1 should be about innovation and every time some legal innovation comes up, its banned quickly. See: The F-duct being a "movable aerodynamic device" despite working with no moving parts. If i wanted spec open wheel i'd watch indycar. (And since they are almost oval free at this point i just might). "If it happens in earths atmosphere its an aerodynamic device". -FIArarri.

God forbid someone innovates in f1 in current year.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
Toe in reduces oversteer leading to a more understeer biased front end, not the other way around. The cars running toe out want a direct front end to get the car into a corner for it to use the camber of the geometry of the tyre as quickly as possible.

Toe effects cornering at a different state. Entering and mid corner are two totally different steering effects.

Your explanation doesn’t make sense.
snippet.textOriginal:
Toe in reduces oversteer leading to a more understeer biased front end, not the other way around. The cars running toe out want a direct front end to get the car into a corner for it to use the camber of the geometry of the tyre as quickly as possible. 

Toe effects cornering at a different state. Entering and mid corner are two totally different steering effects.

Your explanation doesn’t make sense.

snippet.textDisplay: Sorry, but doesn't toe out do the exact opposite of what he says it does? From my understanding, when the front tyres are toed out, the inside tyre will scrub more than the outside corner on initial turn-in, causing a rotational acceleration that causes the car to turn in more quickly. It's less stable as a result of this. Not sure about F1, but most other racing series like GT3 would run toe out to improve turn-in.
snippet.textOriginal: Sorry, but doesn't toe out do the exact opposite of what he says it does? From my understanding, when the front tyres are toed out, the inside tyre will scrub more than the outside corner on initial turn-in, causing a rotational acceleration that causes the car to turn in more quickly. It's less stable as a result of this. Not sure about F1, but most other racing series like GT3 would run toe out to improve turn-in.

snippet.textDisplay: I have been wishing cars could do this for the last 10 years playing racing sims. It's always such a struggle finding a toe-out / toe-in settings that works everywhere on the track. For the sake of control and stability it usually end up being a toe-in.
snippet.textOriginal: I have been wishing cars could do this for the last 10 years playing racing sims. It's always such a struggle finding a toe-out / toe-in settings that works everywhere on the track. For the sake of control and stability it usually end up being a toe-in.
